text:
Im experiencing high latency warnings at ~100 markets on flumine. I was wondering best practices broadly speaking for strategy logic so I can improve what I have in my thus far so I can best scale up 

Should not in use market id stand be removed from the strategy?

Is the best way of timing a strategy simply a datetime time stamp comparison at the beginning and end of the process market book function?

I currently have all long running requests executing in workers, but do these effect runtime if executing too often. I have 5 running polling various APIs every 20-30 second. 

For code executing in process market book and process orders should the length of this be limited to 100 lines for example after which conflation is necessary?

Sorry for question dump, any other general pointers to improve speed would be also be greatly appreciated. Cheers!

text: thread pool being exhausted = to many tasks? (work_queue_size is 0 in this warning message, however i highest i saw was 38 i think)

elements.text: Its a single core instance running 2 strategies, processing_market_book shouldnt be to intensive

text: Looking back at the logs, i certainly got these messages since adding the 2nd strat, however the process_market_book is super slim in this one. Could there be any other cause?

elements.text: Looking back at the logs, i certainly got these messages since adding the 2nd strat, however the process_market_book is super slim in this one. Could there be any other cause?

text: Could placing a lot of bets on a single market_book update cause these warnings?

elements.text: Could placing a lot of bets on a single market_book update cause these warnings?

text: This sounds like an issue with the thread pool used for placing bets, nothing to do with the speed of processing market books

elements.text: This sounds like an issue with the thread pool used for placing bets, nothing to do with the speed of processing market books

text: So to many bets placed at once is the issue? This could make sense with the new strategy i added. Any solutions for this?

elements.text: So to many bets placed at once is the issue? This could make sense with the new strategy i added. Any solutions for this?

text: Seems very likely yes

elements.text: Seems very likely yes

text:
A couple of thoughts bearing in mind I have no idea of the flumine internals:

1. Increase the thread pool size (looks like it's 32)
2. Group the bets so you're placing multiple per placeOrders call and minimising the number of calls you're making

elements.text: A couple of thoughts bearing in mind I have no idea of the flumine internals:
Increase the thread pool size (looks like it's 32)
Group the bets so you're placing multiple per placeOrders call and minimising the number of calls you're making

text:
so just to get it right: the way to go about this would be
1. create a trade
2. create bunch of orders for that trade
3. 
```        with market.transaction() as t:
            for o in trade.orders:
                t.place_order(o)```
and i m good?

elements.text: so just to get it right: the way to go about this would be

create bunch of orders for that trade
and i m good?

text: just tested, everything seems to be working fine. Thanks guys! Also this is now only a single transaction? (regarding my 5k transaction limit per hour) ? If so, thats pretty neat, both problems solved in one

text:
So few things,

 the market / order streams are in separate threads and main handles the market updates/processing so a slow strategy wont cause conflation
 workers are also threads so dont impact anything else (unless they are CPU heavy / bound)
 100 markets is small and will be very light on cpu 
 check your clock is correct 
 lines are meaningless, it will be what you are doing 
 what are you doing?
 cprofilev is very good at finding slow code

elements.text: So few things,
the market / order streams are in separate threads and main handles the market updates/processing so a slow strategy wont cause conflation
workers are also threads so dont impact anything else (unless they are CPU heavy / bound)
100 markets is small and will be very light on cpu
check your clock is correct
lines are meaningless, it will be what you are doing
what are you doing?
cprofilev is very good at finding slow code

text: I will break down the runtime of each section to find out what are the slowest functions. Regarding number of markets I've recently got the limit increased from 200 to 1000 per connection but I believe I am filtering them the wrong way. I'm basically putting into a list the games closest to market open in a worker then in PMB checking if it is in this list . I feel this is cumbersome as the connections to the ~700 markets available are getting set up and then not being used. Is there a better practice for initialising markets that are desired. Similarly where is the base code "Middleware" that executes when you start framework.run() as this adds all the available markets and then I have to filter them when I'd quite like to do this the opposite way round ie filter then add based on time to ko
